Stories published in 2020

Office of the President — July 14, 2020

Update for our international students Link: https://president.stanford.edu/2020/07/14/update-for-our-international-students/

In a message to the campus community, President Marc Tessier-Lavigne discusses the federal government’s decision to rescind its July 6 guidance requiring nonimmigrant students who are not taking in-person classes in fall 2020 to leave the United States.

July 14, 2020

Methane emissions climb Link: https://news.stanford.edu/2020/07/14/methane-emissions-climb/

The pandemic has tugged carbon emissions down, temporarily. But levels of the powerful heat-trapping gas methane continue to climb, dragging the world further away from a path that skirts the worst effects of global warming.

July 13, 2020

Stanford joins legal actions seeking to block federal rule affecting international students with F-1 visas Link: https://news.stanford.edu/2020/07/13/stanford-joins-legal-actions-seeking-block-federal-rule-affecting-international-students-f-1-visas/

Stanford joined colleges and universities in the western U.S. in a lawsuit challenging the federal rule and joined another set of institutions in an amicus brief supporting another challenge. Stanford also is extending support and providing information to international students.

July 13, 2020

Stanford expedites review of requests for Jordan Hall renaming and statue removal Link: https://news.stanford.edu/2020/07/13/stanford-expedites-review-requests-jordan-hall-renaming-statue-removal/

President Marc Tessier-Lavigne has appointed a committee and asks that it make its recommendations by the beginning of the fall quarter in September.

July 13, 2020

Stanford University Board of Trustees elects four new members Link: https://news.stanford.edu/2020/07/13/stanford-university-board-trustees-elects-four-new-members-2/

The new trustees, selected through the alumni nominations process, will begin their six-year terms on Oct. 1.

July 13, 2020

Stanford writing lecturers and students find their virtual footing Link: https://news.stanford.edu/2020/07/13/stanford-writing-lecturers-students-find-virtual-footing/

During spring quarter, when students were learning from home, lecturers in the Program in Writing and Rhetoric created supportive virtual writing classrooms.

July 10, 2020

Suspending international student visas will harm the economy Link: https://news.stanford.edu/2020/07/10/suspending-international-student-visas-will-harm-economy/

International students drive creativity and innovation in the U.S. and help make American universities more competitive, according to Ran Abramitzky, an economic historian who studies immigration impacts.

July 9, 2020

One-year delay in unit cap on undergraduate majors approved Link: https://news.stanford.edu/2020/07/09/steering-committee-discussion-delay-policy-capping-units/

The Steering Committee of the Faculty Senate approved a one-year delay on a new academic policy – which had been scheduled to go into effect in the 2020-21 academic year – setting a 100-unit cap on undergraduate majors.

July 9, 2020

Haas Center adapts to the pandemic Link: https://news.stanford.edu/2020/07/09/haas-center-adapts-pandemic/

Since the outbreak of COVID-19, Stanford’s Haas Center for Public Service has identified and connected students to remote learning, service and career opportunities.

Stanford Law School — July 9, 2020

Stanford Law’s David Sklansky on SCOTUS rulings about President Trump financial records Link: https://law.stanford.edu/2020/07/09/stanford-laws-david-sklansky-on-scotus-rulings-re-president-trump-financial-records/

The U.S. Supreme Court ruled on Thursday, July 9, on two important presidential power cases. Stanford Law Professor David Sklansky discusses the two decisions and their implications.
